metadata./Keywords: Vitreous occlusion; Ahmed glaucoma valve implant; Intraocular pressure
metadata./Title: Partial vitreous occlusion of Ahmed glaucoma valve implant with controlled intraocular pressure: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background The Ahmed glaucoma valve implant is effective in reducing intraocular pressure, yet it poses a risk 
of complications such as vitreous occlusion of the tube, potentially resulting in elevated intraocular pressure or retinal issues. Here, I report a distinctive case of partial vitreous occlusion of an Ahmed glaucoma valve implant wherein 
intraocular pressure could be controlled with the use of topical antiglaucoma medications.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation An 86-year-old Korean male with primary open-angle glaucoma in the left eye underwent 
Ahmed glaucoma valve implantation due to uncontrolled intraocular pressure despite maximal medical treatment. 
At postoperative 1-month, partial vitreous occlusion of the Ahmed glaucoma valve tube with intraocular pressure 
elevation to 25 mmHg was identified. Despite persistent occlusion after neodymium:yttrium–aluminum–garnet 
laser vitreolysis, stable intraocular pressure was achieved with the use of topical antiglaucoma medications throughout the entire follow-up period up to 6 months postoperatively, without retinal complications.
Conclusions This report highlights a unique instance of partial vitreous occlusion of an Ahmed glaucoma valve 
implant in which intraocular pressure could be managed with medical therapy. In cases where complete vitreous 
removal is not feasible, close monitoring is recommended for prompt detection and management of potential 
complications.
Keywords  Vitreous occlusion, Ahmed glaucoma valve implant, Intraocular pressure
Background
The Ahmed glaucoma valve (AGV) implant, a glaucoma 
drainage device that evacuates aqueous humor to an 
external reservoir, has been shown to be effective in low ering intraocular pressure (IOP) [1, 2]. However, postop erative complications also have been reported, including 
hypotony, excessive capsule fibrosis and clinical failure, 
vitreous occlusion of the tube, erosion of the tube or 
plate edge, strabismus, and infection [3–5].Among the complications, vitreous occlusion of an 
AGV implant tube is rare but potentially devastating, as 
it could lead to elevated IOP due to obstruction of aque ous outflow or retinal issues such as retinal detachment 
caused by vitreous traction. Previous studies have docu mented cases wherein occlusion was effectively managed 
through laser treatment or surgery [6, 7]. However, there 
have been no reports of partial vitreous occlusion of the 
tube, nor of any instances where the IOP was stabilized 
with medical treatment.
In this case report, I present a unique instance of partial 
vitreous occlusion of an AGV implant wherein IOP could 
be controlled through utilization of topical antiglaucoma 
medications.Open Access

Case presentation
An 86-year-old Korean male with primary open-angle 
glaucoma in the left eye visited our ophthalmology clinic 
with uncontrolled IOP despite maximal medical treat ment. He had undergone cataract surgery at 45 and 
72 years of age in the right and left eye, respectively, as 
well as penetrating keratoplasty twice in the right eye at 
67 and 74 years of age, the latter two cases due to bullous 
keratopathy. He had no family history of ocular disease. 
At the same visit, he had no light perception in the right 
eye due to corneal graft rejection, and the best-corrected 
visual acuity (BCVA) in the left eye was 20/25. His IOP 
was 12 mmHg and 30 mmHg in the right and left eyes, 
respectively, as measured by Goldmann applanation 
tonometry, despite using topical antiglaucoma medi cations—latanoprost once daily and brimonidine and 
dorzolamide-timolol twice daily—in the left eye. Ante rior-segment examination of the left eye showed vitreous 
prolapse, which was confined adjacent to the pupillary 
margin, and gonioscopy revealed an open angle. Further 
examination of the left optic nerve revealed glaucoma tous optic nerve head cupping with a vertical cup-to-disc 
ratio of 0.7 and diffuse thinning of the retinal nerve fiber 
layer (RNFL) on both RNFL photography (Vx-10; Kowa 
Optimed, Tokyo, Japan) and optical coherence tomogra phy (Cirrus HD-OCT; Carl Zeiss Meditec, Dublin, CA, 
USA) with corresponding superior and inferior visual 
field defects measured by standard automated perimetry 
(Humphrey Field Analyzer II; Carl Zeiss Meditec). Given 
the uncontrolled IOP despite maximal medical treat ment, AGV implantation was performed in the left eye.
On the first postoperative day, his IOP had decreased 
to 8  mmHg in the left eye, and the AGV tube was pat ent. Therefore, we recommended that he discontinue 
using topical antiglaucoma medications and start on postoperatively prescribed eyedrops including topical 
antibiotics and a steroid. At postoperative 1-week, his 
BCVA was 20/28 while the IOP remained stable, which 
was 9 mmHg in the left eye.
At postoperative 1-month, the IOP in the left eye 
was elevated to 25  mmHg, and partial vitreous occlu sion of the AGV tube was identified. Fundus photogra phy and optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed 
a flat retina without cystoid macular edema. To release 
the occlusion, neodymium:yttrium–aluminum-garnet 
(Nd:YAG) laser vitreolysis (32 shots, 6.0–8.0 mJ) directed 
at a vitreous strand was performed. Also, we prescribed 
for the left eye, additionally to the postoperative eyed 
rops, the topical medications latanoprost (once daily) 
and dorzolamide-timolol (twice daily). Two days postlaser treatment, the IOP was normalized to 9  mmHg 
with persistent partial vitreous occlusion of the AGV 
tube (Fig.  1). Anterior-segment OCT also confirmed the 
vitreous strand occluding the tube (Fig.  2). We planned 
either to repeat Nd:YAG laser vitreolysis or perform an 
anterior vitrectomy. However, as the patient declined any 
Fig. 1 Anterior-segment photography of patient. A Left-eye partial vitreous occlusion of Ahmed glaucoma valve tube with vitreous strand (white 
arrow). B Magnified view of vitreous occlusion of tube
Fig. 2 Anterior-segment optical coherence tomography of patient 
showing left-eye partial vitreous occlusion of Ahmed glaucoma valve 
tube by vitreous strand (white arrow)
Page 3 of 4
 Lee  Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:592 
 
additional laser treatment or surgery, we revised our plan 
to close monitoring for potential elevation in IOP result ing from further vitreous occlusion or retinal issues such 
as detachment caused by vitreous traction.
Thereafter, the IOP remained stable throughout 
the entire follow-up period: 10  mmHg, 8  mmHg, and 
9 mmHg at 2 months, 3 months, and 6 months postop eratively, respectively, without any retinal complications.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
Prompt intervention may be necessary to mechanically 
release vitreous occlusion of an AGV implant tube in 
instances where complete occlusion
sections.Results:
results in uncon trolled elevation of IOP despite medical treatment. For tunately, our patient experienced only partial occlusion 
of the tube, and his IOP could be controlled using antiglaucoma medications. There are two possible expla nations for the partial occlusion: first, the amount of 
vitreous might have been too small to completely occlude 
the tube inlet; second, as our preoperative examination 
revealed, the vitreous was confined around the pupillary 
margin, which might have made for insufficient proxim ity between the vitreous and the tube inlet.
Regarding IOP , there was an unexpected rise noted in 
our patient at postoperative 1-month, which contrasted 
with the earlier postoperative periods. Two mechanisms 
may have contributed to this: first, partial vitreous occlu sion of the tube could have resulted in decreased aque ous outflow; second, the patient might have been going 
through a hypertensive phase, which is characterized by 
an IOP rise secondary to bleb encapsulation that peaks 
at postoperative 1-month in patients undergoing AGV 
implantation [8, 9]. It is possible that the combined 
actions of the two mechanisms synergistically led to ele vation of IOP in our patient.
In the literature, a few other cases of postoperative 
ocular hypertension resulting from vitreous occlusion 
of an AGV tube have also been reported [6, 7], although 
the treatment strategies differed from those in the cur rent study. Salvador et  al. [6] related that two patients 
(11.76%) with refractory glaucoma experienced block age of the AGV tube by vitreous after surgery and were 
treated with Nd:YAG laser (one case) and vitrectomy 
(one case). Similarily, a case series by Gu et al. [7] showed 
that three patients with secondary glaucoma had elevated 
IOP due to tube blockage by vitreous, all of which were 
resolved using Nd:YAG laser, resulting in stabilized IOP .
With regard to the types of occlusion, as classified 
by its location, the previous cases [6 , 7] and the pre sent one are similar in that they all involved distal tube 
occlusion, which occurs in the anterior chamber, ciliary 
sulcus, or pars plana [10]. The other type is proximal tube obstruction, which presents at the tube–plate 
junction due to fibrous ingrowth [10, 11]. However, as 
classified by the extent of occlusion, the current case 
was partial tube occlusion, in contrast to the complete 
occlusion observed in the earlier cases [6 , 7].
To sum up, in contrast to the relevant earlier stud ies, in which laser or surgical treatment was performed 
to control IOP , it is noteworthy that we are reporting, 
for the first time, a case of a partially vitreous-occluded 
AGV implant tube, in which IOP could be medically 
controlled. Although complete removal of vitreous 
occlusion is desirable, it is suggested that when this is 
not feasible, close monitoring for possible complica tions such as progression of vitreous occlusion or reti nal diseases arising from vitreous traction is needed.
In
sections.Conclusion:
conclusion, I present herein a special case of 
partial vitreous occlusion of an AGV implant tube, 
wherein IOP could be controlled using topical antiglau coma medications. In cases where removal of vitreous 
is impracticable, close follow-up for potential compli cations including IOP elevation and retinal detachment 
is advisable.
Abbreviations
AGV  Ahmed glaucoma valve
BCVA  Best-corrected visual acuity
IOP  Intraocular pressure
Nd:YAG   Neodymium:yttrium–aluminum–garnet
OCT  Optical coherence tomography
RNFL  Retinal nerve fiber layer
Acknowledgements
Not applicable.
Author contributions
YJL conceived and planned the study, collected and analyzed the data, and 
wrote the manuscript.
Funding
None.
Availability of data and materials
All of the data in this case report are available from the corresponding author 
on reasonable request.
Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Chungnam 
National University Hospital (IRB No. 2024-02-067), and its protocol followed 
the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki. Written informed consent was 
obtained.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of 
this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent 
is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
Competing interests
The author declares no competing interests.
